newsitem.title: USA: FDA advisers vote down Cephalon ALS drug.
newsitem.headline: FDA advisers vote down Cephalon ALS drug.

text.p: A panel of U.S. Food and Drug Administration advisers on Thursday voted 6-3 to reject Cephalon Inc.'s Myotrophin (recombinant human insulin growth factor-1) injection for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), or Lou Gehrig's disease, which kills 10,000 Americans a year and affects up to 30,000.
The panel vote is a defeat for Cephalon, and its partner, Chiron Corp, which had struggled to win FDA approval. The FDA is not bound by the panel's advice, but usually follows it.

ALS causes progressive paralysis and loss of respiratory function. Patients survive only about three years after diagnosis. Close to two dozen ALS patients pleaded for approval of Myotrophin, saying that it would give them hope and time.
But panel chairman Dr Sid Gilman of the University of Michigan Medical Center said that "the data do not look robust, they look modest."

Dr David Drachman, a panelist from the University of Massachusetts, said "My sense is we have seen cosmetic changes in the data," and that the panel was exactly where it was last June --- wanting better and more data.
